item.title: Pokémon Legends: Z-A players have a complicated love for a new Mega Evolution
item.content:encoded:
Pokémon Legends: Z-A players are downright infatuated with one of the more bizarre Mega Evolutions tucked away in the later portion of the game. A Mega Evolution that is making strides in general memery and ridiculous-factor.

Spoilers for what this mysterious Pokémon is below

That Mega Evolution is of course Mega Starmie, which in Pokémon Legends: Z-A has been given a pair of pointy legs it uses to stroll around the place. It's frankly a silly design, one that many players can't help but scratch their heads at. You can see it for yourself below, but it's literally just Starmie with big purple legs.

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

With these legs Mega Starmie has been running around in a peculiar fashion, and that's about it. They don't get any extra gems or a third spinning star on their back. Nope, just legs. It is both incredibly underwhelming and a masterclass in how doing less can sometimes mean doing more. These legs are better eye catchers than the other bells and whistles Pokémon Legends: Z-A has slapped on other Mega Evolutions.

The reaction to these legs has been coming in droves from members of the Pokémon community, who have wasted no time creating art of Starmie's two strong legs. Some believe Starmie's new form to be menacing, having them sprint directly at the viewer with malicious intent.

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

Others, obviously, find Mega Starmie's legs awesome. Some see it as a display of strength, viewing Starmie's legs as bulky pylons on which Mega Starmie asserts its dominance.

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

Others see them as appealing in an altogether different way. As shown below, with user Steve Ly on Twitter who interprets Starmie's new legs as sexy boots, and recreating Patrick Star's provocative dance from The Spongebob Squarepants movie's "I'm a Goofy Goober" song.

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

Others, I believe with justice in their hearts, feel sorry for Mega Starmie and all the ridicule they have been exposed to. To them, Starmie going out there and expressing themselves was a moment of celebration. The online reaction, a moment of tragedy for the starfish.

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

Look, whether you are amused, inspired, aroused, or emotionally attached to Mega Starmie's new legs, there's no debate that Starmie has stolen the show in terms of Pokémon Legends: Z-A Mega Evolutions. All it took was two legs and a funny run. Perhaps in creating such discussion, Mega Starmie's new look has proven itself a masterpiece in virality, and ultimately a success when it comes to taking a beloved Pokémon to new heights. Literally, new heights.

It also turns out Mega Starmie might poop too, yet another nugget of joy from Pokémon Legends: Z-A. If you want to read more about that, you can of course do so on Eurogamer.

Related topics


https://www.eurogamer.net/pokemon-legends-z-a-players-have-a-complicated-love-for-a-new-mega-evolution

item.title: Yes, Pokémon do poop, Legends: Z-A confirms - and have "tummy troubles" too
item.content:encoded:
Do Pokémon poop? Perhaps that's not a question you've ever considered after decades of this franchise's existence, but it's a question that's now been answered in Pokémon Legends: Z-A.

There's certainly some colourful dialogue in this latest Pokémon spin-off (even if it's not voiced, but let's not go there now), but some conversations are proving more revelatory than others.

Japanese fans, as Automaton has reported, have become particularly concerned with an NPC whose Pikachu is "pooping more than usual", leading to "Pikachu's poop" becoming a trending topic on social media.

Eurogamer has spotted the NPC in the English-language version too. "My Pikachu's been having tummy troubles recently," the kid says. "I'm worried…"

The offending Pikachu doesn't look any different standing in front of the child, who sits on a bench showing little actual worry or, you know, helping the poor thing. But maybe this Pikachu is simply putting on a brave face in public, holding it in before scampering to defecate in a nearby bush - hey, we've all been there (the brave face bit at least).

This pair aren't alone either, as Eurogamer also spotted another Pokémon trainer who's been busy "cleaning up the, um, droppings of wild Pokémon". Why are they doing that? The mysteries continue.

Thankfully none of this poop is seen in-game, so the pristine streets of Lumiose City remain smear free.

If you've been wondering how long it takes to run around the city, picking up poop or not, then Eurogamer has investigated for you - it's shorter than you might think.

Related topics


https://www.eurogamer.net/yes-pokemon-do-poop-legends-z-a-confirms-and-have-tummy-troubles-too
